segment.source: Handle device removed scenarios in Direct3D 11
segment.target: Handle device removed scenarios in Direct3D 11

segment.source: This topic explains how to recreate the Direct3D and DXGI device interface chain when the graphics adapter is removed or reinitialized.
segment.target: This topic explains how to recreate the Direct3D and DXGI device interface chain when the graphics adapter is removed or reinitialized.

segment.source: Handle device removed scenarios in Direct3D 11
segment.target: Handle device removed scenarios in Direct3D 11

segment.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive

segment.source: This topic explains how to recreate the Direct3D and DXGI device interface chain when the graphics adapter is removed or reinitialized.
segment.target: This topic explains how to recreate the Direct3D and DXGI device interface chain when the graphics adapter is removed or reinitialized.

segment.source: In DirectX 9, applications could encounter a "device lost" condition where the D3D device enters a non-operational state.
segment.target: In DirectX 9, applications could encounter a "device lost" condition where the D3D device enters a non-operational state.

segment.source: For example, when a full-screen Direct3D 9 application loses focus, the Direct3D device becomes "lost;" any attempts to draw with a lost device will silently fail.
segment.target: For example, when a full-screen Direct3D 9 application loses focus, the Direct3D device becomes "lost;" any attempts to draw with a lost device will silently fail.

segment.source: Direct3D 11 uses virtual graphics device interfaces, enabling multiple programs to share the same physical graphics device and eliminating conditions where apps lose control of the Direct3D device.
segment.target: Direct3D 11 uses virtual graphics device interfaces, enabling multiple programs to share the same physical graphics device and eliminating conditions where apps lose control of the Direct3D device.

segment.source: However, it is still possible for graphics adapter availability to change.
segment.target: However, it is still possible for graphics adapter availability to change.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: The graphics driver is upgraded.
segment.target: The graphics driver is upgraded.

segment.source: The system changes from a power-saving graphics adapter to a performance graphics adapter.
segment.target: The system changes from a power-saving graphics adapter to a performance graphics adapter.

segment.source: The graphics device stops responding and is reset.
segment.target: The graphics device stops responding and is reset.

segment.source: A graphics adapter is physically attached or removed.
segment.target: A graphics adapter is physically attached or removed.

segment.source: When such circumstances arise, DXGI returns an error code indicating that the Direct3D device must be reinitialized and device resources must be recreated.
segment.target: When such circumstances arise, DXGI returns an error code indicating that the Direct3D device must be reinitialized and device resources must be recreated.

segment.source: This walkthrough explains how Direct3D 11 apps and games can detect and respond to any circumstance where the graphics adapter is reset, removed, or changed.
segment.target: This walkthrough explains how Direct3D 11 apps and games can detect and respond to any circumstance where the graphics adapter is reset, removed, or changed.

segment.source: Code examples are provided from the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template provided with Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: Code examples are provided from the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template provided with Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: Instructions
segment.target: Instructions

segment.source: Step 1:
segment.target: Step 1:

segment.source: Include a check for the device removed error in the rendering loop.
segment.target: Include a check for the device removed error in the rendering loop.

segment.source: Present the frame by calling IDXGISwapChain::Present (or Present1, and so on).
segment.target: Present the frame by calling IDXGISwapChain::Present (or Present1, and so on).

segment.source: Then, check whether it returned DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED or DXGIERRORDEVICERESET.
segment.target: Then, check whether it returned DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED or DXGIERRORDEVICERESET.

segment.source: First, the template stores the HRESULT returned by the DXGI swap chain:
segment.target: First, the template stores the HRESULT returned by the DXGI swap chain:

segment.source: After taking care of all other work for presenting the frame, the template checks for the device removed error.
segment.target: After taking care of all other work for presenting the frame, the template checks for the device removed error.

segment.source: If necessary, it calls a method to handle the device removed condition:
segment.target: If necessary, it calls a method to handle the device removed condition:

segment.source: Step 2:
segment.target: Step 2:

segment.source: Also, include a check for the device removed error when responding to window size changes.
segment.target: Also, include a check for the device removed error when responding to window size changes.

segment.source: This is a good place to check for DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED or DXGIERRORDEVICERESET for several reasons:
segment.target: This is a good place to check for DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED or DXGIERRORDEVICERESET for several reasons:

segment.source: Resizing the swap chain requires a call to the underlying DXGI adapter, which can return the device removed error.
segment.target: Resizing the swap chain requires a call to the underlying DXGI adapter, which can return the device removed error.

segment.source: The app might have moved to a monitor that's attached to a different graphics device.
segment.target: The app might have moved to a monitor that's attached to a different graphics device.

segment.source: When a graphics device is removed or reset, the desktop resolution often changes, resulting in a window size change.
segment.target: When a graphics device is removed or reset, the desktop resolution often changes, resulting in a window size change.

segment.source: The template checks the HRESULT returned by ResizeBuffers:
segment.target: The template checks the HRESULT returned by ResizeBuffers:

segment.source: Step 3:
segment.target: Step 3:

segment.source: Any time your app receives the DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED error, it must reinitialize the Direct3D device and reinitialize any device-dependent resources.
segment.target: Any time your app receives the DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED error, it must reinitialize the Direct3D device and reinitialize any device-dependent resources.

segment.source: Release any references to graphics device resources created with the previous Direct3D device; those resources are now invalid, and all references to the swap chain must be released before a new one can be created.
segment.target: Release any references to graphics device resources created with the previous Direct3D device; those resources are now invalid, and all references to the swap chain must be released before a new one can be created.

segment.source: The HandleDeviceLost method releases the swap chain and notifies app components to release device resources:
segment.target: The HandleDeviceLost method releases the swap chain and notifies app components to release device resources:

segment.source: Then, it creates a new swap chain and reinitializes the device-dependent resources controlled by the device management class:
segment.target: Then, it creates a new swap chain and reinitializes the device-dependent resources controlled by the device management class:

segment.source: After the device and swap chain have been re-established, it notifies app components to reinitialize device-dependent resources:
segment.target: After the device and swap chain have been re-established, it notifies app components to reinitialize device-dependent resources:

segment.source: When the HandleDeviceLost method exits, control returns to the rendering loop, which continues on to draw the next frame.
segment.target: When the HandleDeviceLost method exits, control returns to the rendering loop, which continues on to draw the next frame.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: Investigating the cause of device removed errors
segment.target: Investigating the cause of device removed errors

segment.source: Repeat issues with DXGI device removed errors can indicate that your graphics code is creating invalid conditions during a drawing routine.
segment.target: Repeat issues with DXGI device removed errors can indicate that your graphics code is creating invalid conditions during a drawing routine.

segment.source: It can also indicate a hardware failure or a bug in the graphics driver.
segment.target: It can also indicate a hardware failure or a bug in the graphics driver.

segment.source: To investigate the cause of device removed errors, call ID3D11Device::GetDeviceRemovedReason before releasing the Direct3D device.
segment.target: To investigate the cause of device removed errors, call ID3D11Device::GetDeviceRemovedReason before releasing the Direct3D device.

segment.source: This method returns one of six possible DXGI error codes indicating the reason for the device removed error:
segment.target: This method returns one of six possible DXGI error codes indicating the reason for the device removed error:

segment.source: DXGIERRORDEVICEHUNG: The graphics driver stopped responding because of an invalid combination of graphics commands sent by the app.
segment.target: DXGIERRORDEVICEHUNG: The graphics driver stopped responding because of an invalid combination of graphics commands sent by the app.

segment.source: If you get this error repeatedly, it is a likely indication that your app caused the device to hang and needs to be debugged.
segment.target: If you get this error repeatedly, it is a likely indication that your app caused the device to hang and needs to be debugged.

segment.source: DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED: The graphics device has been physically removed, turned off, or a driver upgrade has occurred.
segment.target: DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED: The graphics device has been physically removed, turned off, or a driver upgrade has occurred.

segment.source: This happens occasionally and is normal; your app or game should recreate device resources as described in this topic.
segment.target: This happens occasionally and is normal; your app or game should recreate device resources as described in this topic.

segment.source: DXGIERRORDEVICERESET: The graphics device failed because of a badly formed command.
segment.target: DXGIERRORDEVICERESET: The graphics device failed because of a badly formed command.

segment.source: If you get this error repeatedly, it may mean that your code is sending invalid drawing commands.
segment.target: If you get this error repeatedly, it may mean that your code is sending invalid drawing commands.

segment.source: DXGIERRORDRIVERINTERNALERROR: The graphics driver encountered an error and reset the device.
segment.target: DXGIERRORDRIVERINTERNALERROR: The graphics driver encountered an error and reset the device.

segment.source: DXGIERRORINVALIDCALL: The application provided invalid parameter data.
segment.target: DXGIERRORINVALIDCALL: The application provided invalid parameter data.

segment.source: If you get this error even once, it means that your code caused the device removed condition and must be debugged.
segment.target: If you get this error even once, it means that your code caused the device removed condition and must be debugged.

segment.source: SOK: Returned when a graphics device was enabled, disabled, or reset without invalidating the current graphics device.
segment.target: SOK: Returned when a graphics device was enabled, disabled, or reset without invalidating the current graphics device.

segment.source: For example, this error code can be returned if an app is using Windows Advanced Rasterization Platform (WARP) and a hardware adapter becomes available.
segment.target: For example, this error code can be returned if an app is using Windows Advanced Rasterization Platform (WARP) and a hardware adapter becomes available.

segment.source: The following code will retrieve the DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED error code and print it to the debug console.
segment.target: The following code will retrieve the DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED error code and print it to the debug console.

segment.source: Insert this code at the beginning of the HandleDeviceLost method:
segment.target: Insert this code at the beginning of the HandleDeviceLost method:

segment.source: For more details, see GetDeviceRemovedReason and DXGIERROR.
segment.target: For more details, see GetDeviceRemovedReason and DXGIERROR.

segment.source: Testing Device Removed Handling
segment.target: Testing Device Removed Handling

segment.source: Visual Studio's Developer Command Prompt supports a command line tool 'dxcap' for Direct3D event capture and playback related to the Visual Studio Graphics Diagnostics.
segment.target: Visual Studio's Developer Command Prompt supports a command line tool 'dxcap' for Direct3D event capture and playback related to the Visual Studio Graphics Diagnostics.

segment.source: You can use the command line option "-forcetdr" while your app is running which will force a GPU Timeout Detection and Recovery event, thereby triggering DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED and allowing you to test your error handling code.
segment.target: You can use the command line option "-forcetdr" while your app is running which will force a GPU Timeout Detection and Recovery event, thereby triggering DXGIERRORDEVICEREMOVED and allowing you to test your error handling code.

segment.source: Note DXCap and its support DLLs are installed into system32/syswow64 as part of the Graphics Tools for Windows 10 which are no longer distributed via the Windows SDK.
segment.target: Note DXCap and its support DLLs are installed into system32/syswow64 as part of the Graphics Tools for Windows 10 which are no longer distributed via the Windows SDK.

segment.source: Instead they are provided via the Graphics Tools Feature on Demand that is an optional OS component and must be installed in order to enable and use the Graphics Tools on Windows 10.
segment.target: Instead they are provided via the Graphics Tools Feature on Demand that is an optional OS component and must be installed in order to enable and use the Graphics Tools on Windows 10.

segment.source: More information on how to Install the Graphics Tools for Windows 10 can be found here: https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/mt125501.aspx#InstallGraphicsTools
segment.target: More information on how to Install the Graphics Tools for Windows 10 can be found here: https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/mt125501.aspx#InstallGraphicsTools
